messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "albsavoia" <albsavoia@...> wrote:
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "CÃ©dric Beust â" " <cbeust@> wrote:
> > Consider the following example: I have to display a sorted list
> > in a web page, and I only have a functional test that verifies
> > that the HTML is correct. My coverage confirms that my ordering
> > logic is run during the tests. In this situation, the ordering
> > logic is private and not directly tested.
> >
> > A user reports that the list is not sorted correctly, and now I
> > find myself with at least two possible locations to
> > investigate: the HTML generation and the sorting logic.
> >
> > If I had written a test for the private sorting logic, I would
> > know right away where the bug is.
>
> Very well put. I believe this would be a great canonical example
> of why peeking into private methods is not only OK, but the
> preferred way to test, in some cases.
>

Why wouldn't this be an indication that there were insufficient
tests? Evidently, the functional test that was supposed to make sure
that the HTML is "correct" didn't actually verify that the elements
(whatever they are) were presented in the correct order. I'm not
sure I understand what "private" means in this scenario. It doesn't
usually mean "can't directly access from a web browser URL".

Jim
